qas.question: What has the UK political system functioned as?

answers.text: a two-party (sometimes called a "two-and-a-half party") system

qas.question: What are the two largest political parties in the UK?

answers.text: Conservative Party and the Labour Party

qas.question: What was the other major party before the Labour party?

answers.text: A plurality voting system usually leads to a two-party system

plausible_answers.text: a two-party (sometimes called a "two-and-a-half party") system

qas.question: What system was created by Maurice Duverger in the UK?
When was Duverger's Law passed in the UK?
How many seats has Maurice Duverger held in Parliament?
What was the only party that helped pass Duverger's Law?
What does allowing Conservatives in government usually lead to?

context: The UK political system, while technically a multi-party system, has functioned generally as <a0_0><b4_0>a two-party (sometimes called a "two-and-a-half party") system<b4_0/><a0_0/>; since <b5_0>the 1920s<b5_0/> the two largest political parties have been the <a1_0>Conservative Party and the Labour Party<a1_0/>. Before <b7_0>the Labour Party<b7_0/> rose in British politics the <a2_0>Liberal Party<a2_0/> was the other major political party along with the Conservatives. Though coalition and minority governments have been an occasional feature of parliamentary politics, the first-past-the-post electoral system used for general elections tends to maintain the dominance of these two parties, though each has in the past century relied upon a third party to deliver a working majority in Parliament. (<a3_0>A plurality voting system usually leads to <b8_0>a two-party system<b8_0/><a3_0/>, a relationship described by Maurice Duverger and known as Duverger's Law.) There are also numerous other parties that hold or have held <b6_0>a number<b6_0/> of seats in Parliament.
